'Ionomics' is the measurement of the total elemental composition of an organism
to address biological problems. Lahner B, Gong J, Mahmoudian M, Smith EL,
Abid KB, Rogers EE, Guerinot ML, Harper JF, Ward JM, McIntyre L, Schroeder JI,
Salt DE (2003) Genomic scale profiling of nutrient and trace elements in
Arabidopsis thaliana. Nat Biotechnol 21: 1215-
1221.[http://www.nature.com/nbt/journal/v21/n10/pdf/nbt865.pdf] Salt
DE (2004) Update on ionomics. Plant Physiology 136: 2451-
2456.[http://www.plantphysiol.org/cgi/reprint/136/1/2451] Questions within
physiology, ecology, evolution, and many other fields can be investigated using
ionomics, often coupled with bioinformatics and other genetic tools. Eide
DJ, Clark S, Nair TM, Gehl M, Gribskov M, Guerinot ML, Harper JF (2005).
Characterization of the yeast ionome: a genome-wide analysis of nutrient mineral
and trace element homeostasis in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Genome Biol 6:R77.[h-
ttp://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/picrender.fcgi?artid=1242212&blobtype=pdf] Robinson AB, Pauling L (1974) Techniques of orthomolecular diagnosis. Clin
Chem 20: 961-965.[http://www.clinchem.org/cgi/reprint/20/8/961] Rus A,
Baxter I, Muthukumar B, Gustin J, Lahner B, Yakubova E and Salt DE (2006)
Natural variants of AtHKT1 enhance Na+ accumulation in two wild populations of
Arabidopsis. PLoS Genet 2(12): e210.[http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/picrender-
.fcgi?artid=1665649&blobtype=pdf] Baxter I, Muthukumar B, Park HC,
Buchner P, Lahner B, Danku J, Zhao K, Lee J, Hawkesford MJ, Guerinot ML, Salt DE
(2008) Variation in Molybdenum Content Across Broadly Distributed Populations of
Arabidopsis thaliana is Controlled By a Mitochondrial Molybdenum Transporter
(MOT1). PLoS Genet 4(2): e1000004.[http://genetics.plosjournals.org/perlserv/?request=get-
document&doi=10.1371%2Fjournal.pgen.1000004.eor] Watanabe T, Broadley
MR, Jansen S, White PJ, Takada J, Satake K, Takamatsu T, Tuah SJ, Osaki M (2007)
Evolutionary control of leaf element composition in plants. New Physiol 174: 516-523.[http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/doi/pdf/10.1111/j.1469-
8137.2007.02078.x?cookieSet=1] Observing an organism's 'ionome' is a
powerful approach to the functional analysis of its genes and the gene networks.
Information about the physiological state of an organism can also be revealed
indirectly through its ionome, for example iron deficiency in a plant can be
identified by looking at a number of other elements, rather than iron
itself. Baxter, I (2009) Ionomics: studying the social network
of mineral nutrients.Curr Opin Plant Biol;12(3):381-
6.[http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2701637/] A more typical
example is in a blood test, where a number of conditions involving nutrition or
disease may be inferred from testing this single tissue for sodium, potassium,
iron, chlorine, zinc, magnesium, calcium and copper. Brody, Tom. Nutritional
Biochemistry. San Diego: Academic Press, 1998.

In practice, the total elemental composition of an organism is rarely
determined. The number and type of elements measured are limited by the
available instrumentation, the assumed value of the element in question, and the
added cost of measuring each additional element. Also, a single tissue may be
measured instead of the entire organism, as in the example given above of a
blood test, or in the case of plants, the sampling of just the leaves or seeds.
These are simply issues of practicality.

Various techniques may be fruitfully used to measure elemental composition.
Among the best are Inductively-Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy
(ICP-OES), Inductively-Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS), X-Ray
Fluorescence (XRF), synchrotron-based microXRF, Young LW, Westcott ND,
Attenkofer K, Reaney MJ (2006). A high-throughput determination of metal
concentrations in whole intact Arabidopsis thalianaseeds using synchrotron-
based X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy. J Synchrotron Radiat 13: 304-
313.[http://journals.iucr.org/s/issues/2006/04/00/hi5577/hi5577.pdf]
and Neutron activation analysis (NAA). This latter technique has been applied
